required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Single Leg Squat Performance in Physically and Non-physically Active Individuals
clinical_study.official_title: Single Leg Squat Performance in Physically and Non-physically Active Individuals: a Cross-sectional Study

brief_summary.textblock: Single-leg squat (SLS) is a functional test visually rated by clinicians for assessing lower limb function as a preventive injury strategy. SLS clinical rating is a qualitative evaluation and it does not count objective outcomes as kinematics data and surface electromyography (sEMG) assessment. Based on the SLS rating, the aims of this study were (i) to determine the clinical rating agreement among six raters and (ii) to assess kinematic and sEMG predictors of good SLS performance in physically and non-physically active individuals.

primary_outcome.description: intra- and inter-rater reliability for six clinicians when performing the SLS clinical rating assessment
intra- and inter-rater reliability for six clinicians when performing the SLS clinical rating assessment
intra- and inter-rater reliability for six clinicians when performing the SLS clinical rating

secondary_outcome.description: The following kinematic variables were considered during the single-leg squat: ipsilateral hip flexion in the lateral plane, hip internal rotation, hip adduction, pelvic obliquity, knee flexion (lateral plane) and medio-lateral displacement (frontal plane).
The surface Electromyography (sEMG) activity of the following muscles were assessed: tensor fasciae latae, rectus femoris, adductor longus, gluteus maximus and transversus abdominis.

arm_group.description: subjects who perform sports activities more than 6 hours per week
subjects who perform less than 2 hours per week of sport activities

intervention.intervention_name: performance of the single leg squat task
intervention.description: The single-leg squat (SLS) is a clinical functional test commonly used to evaluate clinical abnormal movement patterns of the lower limbs in terms of kinetic chain or co-ordinating muscle activity. This scale accounts for the assessment of five dimensions: overall impression, trunk posture, pelvis in space, hip joint motion and knee join motion. The SLS is potentially promising as a functional test since it involves both daily activity and athletic task.

study_pop.textblock: A cohort of healthy young subjects was recruited.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- body mass index (BMI) between 18.5-25.5,
- age between 18-35 years old,
- written informed consent to participate,
Exclusion Criteria:
- musculoskeletal pain or history of lower extremity injuries lasting more than three months
